title: The Name of the Wind
author: Patrick Rothfuss
notes: A beautifully written first-person narrative. Magic system feels original.

title: Dune
author: Frank Herbert
notes: Dense political ecology. Atreides and Harkonnen dynamics are gripping.

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
notes: System 1 and System 2 thinking. Excellent review of cognitive biases.

title: A Short History of Nearly Everything
author: Bill Bryson
notes: Wonderfully accessible overview of natural science from Big Bang to today.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
notes: Raskolnikov is one of literature's most psychologically complex protagonists.

title: The Pragmatic Programmer
author: David Thomas
notes: DRY, orthogonality, tracer bullets. Essential reading for software developers.

title: Ender's Game
author: Orson Scott Card
notes: Short but punchy. The twist at the end still hits hard on rereads.

title: The Midnight Library
author: Matt Haig
notes: A meditation on regret and possibility. Nora Seed is deeply relatable.

title: Zero: The Biography of a Dangerous Idea
author: Charles Seife
notes: Surprisingly thrilling for a book about a number. Covers theology and calculus.

title: Norwegian Wood
author: Haruki Murakami
notes: Melancholic and beautiful. Loss and memory handled with extraordinary gentleness.

title: Small Great Things
author: Jodi Picoult
notes: Challenging and necessary. Tackles systemic racism through a courtroom drama lens.

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
notes: 1% improvements compounding over time. Practical and immediately actionable.
